definitions.definition: something that you own or have with you at a particular time

examples.text: Prisoners were allowed no personal possessions.
One of Jane's most **prized possessions** was her photo album.
The ring is one of her most treasured possessions.
Please make sure you have all your possessions with you when leaving the plane.
He carried all his worldly possessions in an old suitcase.
The sports car was her proudest possession.

definitions.definition: the state of having or owning something
definitions.sensetop: possession of somethingin somebody's possessionin possession of something

examples.text: The possession of a passport is essential for foreign travel.
They had exclusive possession of the property as tenants.
On her father's death, she **came into possession** of *(= received)* a vast fortune.
You cannot legally **take possession** of the property *(= start using it after buying it)* until three weeks after the contract is signed.
The manuscript is just one of the treasures in their possession.
The gang was caught in possession of stolen goods.
drug possession
weapons/firearms possession

definitions.definition: the state of having control of the ball

examples.text: to **win/get/lose possession** of the ball
The home team had most of the possession in the first half.
The team was struggling to retain possession of the ball.

definitions.definition: the state of having illegal drugs or weapons with you at a particular time

examples.text: She was charged with possession.
They were charged with unlawful possession of firearms.

definitions.definition: a country that is controlled or governed by another country

examples.text: The former colonial possessions are now independent states.
the country's overseas possessions

definitions.definition: the situation when somebody’s mind is believed to be controlled by the Devil or by an evil spirit
if you already have or control something, it is difficult for somebody else to take it away from you, even if they have the legal right to it

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French, from Latin possessio(n-), from the verb possidere, from potis ‘able, capable’ + sedere ‘sit’.
